conclusion: Displacement is the area under the velocity-time graph for a given time interval.
For object A, the area under its v-t graph from 0 to t1 represents its displacement.
For object B, the area under its v-t graph from 0 to t1 represents its displacement.
Both objects start from the origin (0,0) and return to the velocity of zero at time t1.
The graph for object A is above the graph for object B throughout the interval from 0 to t1.
At any given time t within the interval, the velocity of object A is greater than the velocity of object B.
Since the velocity of object A is always greater than that of object B during the interval, the area under the graph for object A will be greater than the area under the graph for object B.
The displacement of object A will be greater than the displacement of object B at any point in time from 0 to t1.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is determined by the difference in the areas under their respective v-t graphs.
Since object A's velocity is always greater than object B's, the difference in displacement between the two objects is continuously increasing throughout the interval from 0 to t1.
The difference in displacement between objects A and B is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
